awd_titl_txt: Advances in Skin Color Measurement: Reliability, Validity, and Feasibility of Portable Devices for Field Research in the Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will advance knowledge of the measurement of skin color in survey field research. Skin color is a frequently used measure of race and ethnicity. Interviewer-coded skin color is simple to collect in the field, but researchers use coarse and subjective categories. Handheld instruments for objective physical measurements of skin color have advantages of increased replicability and precision, but adoption in the social and behavioral sciences has been limited. This project will determine whether a new generation of portable devices for color measurement are practically feasible and scientifically sound for use in measuring human skin tone in large-scale field-based survey research. The investigators also will seek to better understand how physical measures of skin color compare to interviewer-coded skin color scales. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved throughout the project. Results will be disseminated not only to other scholars and teachers, but also to policymakers, practitioners, and the broader public.

This research project will conduct the empirical and translational work necessary to bring tools for measurement of skin color into broad use in field settings in the social, behavioral, and economic sciences. Although handheld devices have been widely used in some fields of medicine and physical anthropology, there is varying standardization of measurement protocol and little adoption in other fields. This project will evaluate the reliability of handheld measurement devices and of self- and interviewer-rated categorical scales of skin color; establish their validity in relation to social, behavioral, and academic outcomes; and assess the feasibility of each approach. The study population will include individuals from a wide range of racial and ethnic backgrounds, drawing from a data collection site at one of the most diverse universities in the country. Specific guidance regarding methods of skin color measurement for field-based studies will be produced, along with cost information, technical recommendations, and template research protocols and budget sheets. By generating these resources, the project will improve both internal and external validity of skin color data, facilitating cross-sample and cross-cohort comparisons. The investigators will identify the strengths and limitations of conventional skin color rating scales that primarily assess a single dimension of lightness-to-darkness, providing evidence of the need to incorporate measures of undertones (such as redness and yellowness) to better align with contemporary multifaceted and fluid conceptions of race-ethnicity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project accomplished three objectives: 1) demonstrated the reliability of handheld devices and of self-rating scales of skin color; 2) established their validity in relation to important social, behavioral, and academic outcomes; and, 3) assessed the feasibility of using each approach. While doing so, the project identified the relative merits of alternative strategies for measuring skin color, and translated the technical terminology of the science of color measurement for social, behavioral, and economic scientists. The project offers specific guidance for future studies’ assessment of skin color. This project started on September 1, 2019, and was impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic that began six months later in Spring 2020. As a result, we met our objectives while completing less in-person data collection than originally planned and increasing online data collection. 


Our results contributed evidence about each of our three focal objectives:


1) Regarding our first objective of assessing reliability, we generally found that both handheld devices and rating scales of skin color offered reliable assessments of skin shade (lightness-darkness). The choices that human raters made regarding which lighter-or-darker color swatch best matches an observed person’s skin color were highly associated with readings taken using mechanical devices that measured darkness by the amount of light reflected off the skin. Measurements of skin undertone (redness, yellowness) were less reliable, both when measured by handheld devices and by human raters.


Our results also showed that variations in skin undertone (redness, yellowness) were greatest in the middle range of skin shade (lightness-darkness), and that some of the categorical skin color rating scales commonly used in social surveys do not represent the full spectrum of skin shades and undertones. More recently developed rating scales based on color science showed more even spacing and better coverage across the diverse range of human skin colors.


2) Regarding validity, we found that people recognized the skin color differences measured by our scales to be socially meaningful. Across racial-ethnic groups, when one set of people rated a photographed individual as having darker skin, another set of people expected that person to experience more social disadvantage, such as being more likely to be arrested when stopped for speeding and less likely to have their symptoms taken seriously by a doctor. Although skin undertones were less consistently associated with such anticipated social experiences, skin yellowness was associated with some of them.


Our findings also suggested ways in which using color-science-based skin color scales may improve upon the skin color rating scales most commonly used in social surveys. For instance, although human ratings of darker skin color generally went hand-in-hand with darker readings using mechanical devices, humans tended to choose darker swatches for darker-skinned and lighter swatches for lighter-skinned individuals than the device-measured values. Additional surveys using photographs of Black-identified and Latino-identified individuals will inform their particular experiences with colorism and how they can be addressed.


3) Regarding feasibility, we found that recently developed smaller and less expensive handheld devices worked nearly as well as larger and more expensive devices. This was particularly true for skin shade. Skin darkness was captured similarly by all devices, and just one or two device readings were sufficient to obtain a stable measurement. On the other hand, skin undertones of redness and yellowness differed more across device settings (size of opening that light passed through) and body locations (cheek versus arm).


We also demonstrated that people can effectively choose a single color swatch out of a large array of 66 swatches (11 levels of darkness by 6 levels of undertone). Survey platforms allow user-friendly presentation of the full array of color swatch choices directly underneath a photograph of a face, and human raters can click to choose the swatch they perceive as best matching the skin color of the person in the photograph. Future efforts can build upon ours to consider what presentations of skin color scales individuals find most user-friendly for choosing the shade and undertone of their own and others skin. Such efforts will be of particular value in understanding why skin undertone is easier to reliably measure than skin shade.


We disseminated our results through scientific papers, including four published at the time of this report, one under review, and others in preparation. We also disseminated results through presentations at scientific meetings and by working directly with companies producing handheld devices and researchers designing and implementing studies. We posted some of our study documentation in open archives and prepared others for sharing.


Our project was co-created by faculty and students, from the development of preliminary evidence to the submission of a proposal for funding to completion and dissemination of findings. We engaged numerous undergraduate students throughout the project, including some funded by Research Experiences for Undergraduates. These students enriched the project, and their engagement supported their pathways to graduate and professional school and careers.
